_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The City of Nicholasville operates a drinking water processing plant in compliance with all federal, state.
and local regulations. The Water Treatment Plant is located southeast of the center of town at 595 Water
Works Road. There have been no accidents which exposed the community to toxic chemicals. 

All operations at the plant are designed and operated to the highest safety standards, and all operating
personnel are certified by the state of Kentucky. In the purification of water the process utilizes chlorine
gas in 1-ton cylinders. Chlorine gas is known to be an extremely toxic and corrosive gas. In order to
provide safe working conditions for the employees, a safety system is in place.  The primary safety system
for the chlorine consists of one chlorine leak detector located in the chlorinating room. The detector is
calibrated to react with a minimum of 1 PPM chlorine gas. If a chlorine gas leak is detected, an internal
alarm is within the room is activated, and a red flashing light will be activated, and an alarm condition
will appear on the monitor of the computer control system.  

Realizing the possibility of exposing the public to leaks from the plant, a process hazard review and risk
assessment has been performed to determine what could possibly happen and what the proper emergency
response should be.  

Fortunately, present analysis indicated that the most likely scenario would be a leak in the tubing in the
process area. Such a leak would be limited to an area approximately one half mile around the center of the
plant. All local emergency response agencies and the state agencies are aware of this exposure, and have
in place specific response processes. 

This Risk Management Procedure (RMP) is for your use. Additional or more detailed information can be
made available. The city of Nicholasville will continue to review  the risks to our community and update
our training and emergency response procedures.
